Breeding programmes give protection: animals born in zoos can be released into the wild to increase genetic diversity.

These types of accidents are very rare. Boats and trains can cause a bridge to collapse, but for different reasons. With trains, it's the speed of the impact that can cause a bridge to collapse. With boats, it's their large size and weight that can cause a collapse, even if they're moving slowly. The best way to avoid bridge collapses is to plan for them. Modern technologies that can find structural weaknesses, safer work environments, and better designs can all help reduce these terrible accidents.

At first, Pi is very scared of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he thinks about the hungry sharks swimming nearby and sees that his only choice is to get back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other, until only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger, which he calls Richard Parker, feels seasick and does not want to eat him right away.

When Pi is 16, a new government wins the election. His parents don't like this government. They are worried about what will happen in the future, so they decide to close their zoo and move to Canada. They sell some of their animals to zoos in North America. The family travels by ship to Canada and takes the remaining animals with them. During the trip, there is a very bad storm and the ship goes down into the ocean. Sadly, Pi's family and all the people working on the ship die in the water. But Pi survives and finds himself on a small rescue boat with a hyena, zebra, orang-utan and a very big tiger.

The Hunger Games is a very popular book for teenagers and young adults, written by American author Suzanne Collins. Since it came out in 2008, it has been translated into 26 languages and sold millions of copies worldwide. It was also the first young readers' book to sell over a million digital copies. The book has been made into a big Hollywood movie, which is also very successful. In its first weekend in North America, it earned 152.5 million dollars!

Dreams might be our mind sorting through the thoughts we have during the day, but they appear in a symbolic way. When we're awake, our thoughts are mostly in words, like the conversations we have with ourselves. When we're asleep, the part of the brain that handles language isn't as active, while the part that deals with emotions becomes more active.

Having good relationships is very important for happiness. In one study, most happy people had close relationships with friends and family and spent time with them often. It’s important to have at least one person you can talk to about your personal feelings – this is called ‘self-disclosure’. Just having one person to share your feelings with, along with other friends, is enough. It’s not enough to have many friends just to do things with or talk about things like music or football. A deeper connection is very important. Some people need to learn how to listen better to others to build stronger relationships.

Carol Dweck, a psychologist who supports the idea of a 'growth mindset,' talked about how our brains can change and grow. She explained that we can develop skills and talents that we weren’t necessarily good at from the beginning. When we praise others, we often focus on their results or natural talents, like saying, "You really have an eye for details" or "You have a real talent for organizing events." But research shows that if we focus on how people do things and praise their effort, creativity, and problem-solving, we can help them develop new skills and keep improving the ones they have.

The rover checks the air around it regularly. In 2014, it discovered that the air contained methane, a simple organic molecule and a key part of natural gas. Methane does not last long—only a few hundred years—so something on Mars must be creating more of it. NASA says Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at once. The amount of methane goes up and down with the seasons, almost like the planet is breathing it in and out.

Early in her career, Carol Dweck, a psychologist from Stanford University, gave some ten-year-old children problems that were a bit too difficult for them. One group had a positive reaction. They said they loved the challenge and understood that they could get better at things with practice. Dweck says these children had a 'growth mindset' - this means they believe they can improve and develop their abilities. They focus on what they can learn and achieve in the future. But another group of children felt that Dweck was testing how smart they were, and they thought they had failed. These children had a 'fixed mindset' - this means they believe their abilities cannot change or improve. They could not imagine getting better at things. Some of these children said they might cheat next time; others looked for someone who had done worse than them to feel better about themselves.

Horror movies like places where nobody lives. This can be an old hospital, a scary empty house, or a ghost town (a town with no people). There is something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it is also because they are very quiet, which can be scary too. Abandoned places (places that have been left empty) are useful for horror movie directors because it feels more real that there is no phone signal there.

No matter what kind of house it is, the basement is a scary place in horror movies. It is often where something hides or where a dangerous person (a psychopath) keeps their tools. Basements are usually dark and often damp (wet). You can only get to them by a narrow staircase. And basements always feel creepy, even when there is nothing down there.

Gary Collins, a police officer who was not working at the time, was watching the London riots on TV. He quickly recognised some of the people and decided to end his holiday early to help the police. He spent six months looking at CCTV videos and was able to identify 190 people, often just by looking at their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. Even though there were 200,000 hours of video, the computer software for recognising faces could only identify one person.

Personally, I think it's very interesting to think about how we'll make our evolution as humans faster by adding technology to our bodies. Imagine if you could put a computer inside our brain! Soon we'll be able to do exactly that and make our math skills better, improve how we see and hear things, and make our memory stronger. This idea will become more and more normal in the future.

The talk was really interesting and the speaker said some things that were absolutely right. For example, let's look at how parents influence their children. If parents are always checking their social media while doing other things, like cooking dinner or waiting for the traffic light to turn green, how can we expect teenagers not to do the same while doing their homework? The speaker also made a good point about people wanting to be in many places at the same time. This means they keep switching between talking to people in person and talking to people online. I see this happening a lot with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet up, but then they sit together in silence, each one chatting with someone else online.

Some news stories make it seem like the world is becoming more violent, but there is reason to be hopeful. From the end of World War II to 1990, there were 30 wars that killed over 100,000 people each. Today, there are still civil wars, but overall, countries are more peaceful than before. However, terrorism has increased in recent years. Since World War II, more civilians than soldiers have died in wars. Still, the situation for civilians is not all bad. Although people are nine times more likely to die from violent crime than from war, the global murder rate has gone down slightly—from 8 per 100,000 people in 2000 to about 5.3 in 2015.

Wasfia has spent her life fighting for human rights and has seen many international projects in Bangladesh that aim to educate and train women and girls. But too often, when these projects end, nothing lasting remains. Wasfia believed Bangladesh needed to change from within. So, she combined her two passions—mountaineering and human rights—to challenge how women are seen in her country. She first started climbing while working on aid projects in Tibet and Nepal. In Bangladesh, a flat, coastal country, most people have never seen a mountain. Now, her efforts are making a difference. People in Bangladesh—and around the world—are starting to pay attention.

Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation: very poor, ruled by dictators, and with little hope for improvement. But this is not true. In fact, things are changing a lot. In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have earned more money and are no longer poor. Also, six million fewer children die from diseases every year, millions more girls are going to school, and many more people now have clean water to drink.

Many managers try to make feedback more positive by starting and ending with good comments, and putting the criticism in the middle – this is often called the “sandwich method”. However, if feedback is given this way too often, employees might think the positive comments aren’t sincere, and are just used to make the criticism seem softer. This can make the good comments less meaningful. Instead of using positive feedback to soften bad news, managers should give praise to encourage and support good work when it happens. This shows employees what they are doing well and helps them to continue performing at a high level.

I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary movie robots like the Terminator crushing human heads. Think about what's happening today: military machines like drones (flying robots without pilots), gun towers and guard robots are already being used to kill people with very little human control. The next step will be robots that work completely alone, following orders but deciding who to kill by themselves. I think this would be completely wrong and dangerous for all humans. We need to be very careful about what we tell machines to do.

More people are learning English than all other languages put together, and it’s spoken in more countries than any other language. But, Chinese has the most people who speak it as their first language. It doesn’t seem to matter how many people grow up speaking a language – that doesn’t affect how many people want to learn it. However, there is a connection between how many people learn a language and how many countries have people who speak it.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about how you did in the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, thinking about what you might have done wrong. When you go into her office on Monday morning, she starts by saying good things about your work on the project. You wonder if this is the praise that always comes before criticism - you know this pattern: say something nice, then say what they really think, then say something nice again.

A fast, exciting rock album, Born in the USA has songs with deep feelings. The music sounds happy and catchy, but the words tell sad stories about the American dream - the idea that anyone can become successful in America. Many songs are about ordinary working people who struggle in life and feel angry because they don't get rich or famous. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town who remember when they were young and felt like anything was possible. Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart when he loses his job. You can easily imagine that the singer is thinking about real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become famous. The album clearly shows the amazing talent of the Boss (Bruce Springsteen's nickname).

Lewis wants to see more protected sea areas around the world. Right now, only 3 per cent of the ocean is protected, but he thinks this should grow to 10 per cent. This would help fix the damage that people have caused by catching too many fish, polluting the water, and throwing rubbish into the sea. During his swimming trips, Lewis has seen this environmental damage himself. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water is getting warmer. He has also seen underwater areas in the Red Sea that look like deserts - with no sea life and covered in plastic waste. Pugh believes that nature can get better if we give it the chance, but time is running out. If we don't start taking care of our oceans now, we may soon have a problem that we cannot fix.

Best‑selling author Terrie Sharp knows how to tell a good story – she has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice (a prize for crime novels). She was born in the housing estate in Glasgow with the highest crime rate. There she learned to stay quiet, avoid trouble and even how to open car doors with a knife. Fortunately, she only used this knowledge for her books. Today she is not quiet any more; she appears on popular daytime shows such as *Police Today* and speaks at writing conferences across the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible?  In the book *Enlightenment Now*, Steven Pinker looks at the whole picture of human progress and finds good news. We now live longer, are healthier, have more freedom and are happier. Pinker says the real problem is that the ideas of the Enlightenment – mainly using reason (thinking logically) and science – are being attacked. When commentators and demagogues (people who try to gain power by using strong emotions and lies) appeal to people’s tribalism (strong loyalty to their own group), fatalism (the belief that nothing can change) and distrust, we risk causing serious, lasting damage to important institutions such as democracy and world cooperation.

In old horror movies, when the main characters were in trouble, they often couldn't call for help or phone the police. Today, that’s harder to believe because most people have mobile phones. So how do filmmakers keep the tension? By removing phone service! If you're the hero in a horror movie, it’s almost guaranteed that when you really need to call for help, there will be no signal. Or your phone battery will die just as you try to make the call. Sometimes, both things happen.

In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America were losing their most profitable banana, the Gros Michel, also called Big Mike. Now, the same thing is happening to its replacement – the Cavendish banana. The Gros Michel was popular because its fruit was sweet, had thick skin, and was easy to transport. It grew widely on large farms in Central America. United Fruit, the main company growing and selling bananas in South America at the time, produced them very efficiently. Instead of growing plants from seeds, they used cuttings from banana plant stems – a method called cloning. They planted these close together in large fields.

Most spiders have venom to catch their food, not to hurt people. Only 25 types of spiders have venom that can harm humans, and even though their bites can hurt, they are almost never deadly. For example, Australia’s dangerous Sydney funnel-web spider hasn’t caused any deaths since 1981, when a medicine (anti-venom) was made to treat its bites. But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can shoot out tiny, irritating hairs to protect themselves. These hairs can stick to your skin or eyes and cause discomfort.

This common horror‑movie idea was very popular in movies made in the late 1900s. It begins with a group of teenagers having fun, and it ends with everyone dead except one girl. At first the girl is innocent, shy, and not very strong. By the end she becomes the toughest and most clever person – she can solve problems and use what she has. The last girl almost always wins.

To understand where our ability to use complex language comes from, we need to compare our brains to those of other animals. It’s not just about the size of the brain—it’s also about what the brain can do and how it developed over time. Unfortunately, there are very few physical clues from our ancestors that show us what kind of speech they could produce. However, we can see changes in the bones of early humans, especially in their mouths, throats, and tongues. By around 100,000 years ago, humans had developed the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only guess whether early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.

It is society, not nature, that says girls should like arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to boys. At the same time, there are few positive female role models for young people in science jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, the genius inventor, or the adventurous astronaut as a man. Also, many people think scientists are geeky, have poor social skills, or that their work is lonely and far from everyday life. These are false stereotypes shown by the media, but they can make girls feel they do not belong in science and see it as an unattractive career. If girls saw more positive female role models in science, they would feel more confident and more like they belong in those subjects.

The Scallion is a newspaper that comes out every week and is given out for free in university buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce the whole newspaper themselves. A survey shows that students and staff at the university really value the newspaper for fun, learning about culture, and getting work experience. However, printing the newspaper is expensive. Also, some students can't easily get a copy because they have to physically go to the university to get one. Another problem is that many copies are thrown away and become litter on campus, which is bad for the environment.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our employees leave the company each year. This number might not seem very high, but the normal rate in our industry is only 7%. The main goal of this report is to find out why employees are not as happy or involved at work as they could be. Then, based on these reasons, we will suggest ways to make the workplace better and help employees stay with the company longer.

I really agree with what the speaker said. I think there’s a problem: the more we connect online, the lonelier we might feel. This isn’t such a big issue for my generation because we grew up without so much technology. We know how to be alone, and we understand that being alone is fine. But young people under 20 are different. They spend so much time messaging others that they never really experience being alone. Because of this, they might not learn to enjoy their own company. Also, they learn to talk through messages that can be edited, which means they might not develop the skill of having real conversations face-to-face.

Don’t always put a negative comment after a positive one. If you always mix positive and negative feedback together, the good comments can lose their value and be ignored. Make sure you sometimes give positive feedback just because it is positive, and try not to feel the urge to give constructive criticism (helpful advice that shows how to improve).
